controller

Class AbstractMasterController

  • java.lang.Object
    • controller.AbstractMasterController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.beans.PropertyChangeListener, java.util.EventListener
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MasterController

    public abstract class AbstractMasterController
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.beans.PropertyChangeListener
    An abstract implementation of a "master-controller" for managing actionable logic in a program. Master-controller implementations, along with their related sub-controllers, are intended for large and complex programs, where the amount of actionable methods would clutter up and create chaos in a single program-wide controller.

    The master-controller functions as the bridge between its sub-controllers and all other aspects of the program. References to the master-controller are shared throughout the program, to models, views, and other items. Whenever an event that requires a change in the program's state, or some other sophisticated response, the event and the information needed to execute it is passed along to the master-controller, which then passes it along to the various sub-controllers attached to it. The master controller knows very little about the event, what it's doing, or where it needs to go. All of that is contained with the sub-controllers, which then proceed to parse the event and determine if it is one that they will need to respond to. If an event doesn't apply to a sub-controller, their default implementation is to do nothing (and anyone writing an implementation of the SubController interface is advised to maintain that behavior barring a VERY good reason to change it).

    The master-controller is not merely a dumb pipe through which events flow. It also performs several critical functions that must be implemented in subclasses of this abstract class:

    1) PropertyChangeListener: The master-controller functions as a PropertyChangeListener, receiving PropertyChangeEvents and passing them along to the views that have been registered with this controller. Every property sub-controller added to the property sub-controller list automatically has its this class added to its model as a PropertyChangeListener. If the sub-controller is later removed, the listener is removed automatically from the model.

    2) Instantiation of Sub-Controllers: While not required for an implementation of this class to function, it is highly recommended to incorporate factory methods into a master controller for the creation of the various sub-controllers. While an alternate approach (instantiate an implementation of the SubController interface outside of the master-controller, and pass it in via an add() method) is possible, it creates an additional layer of coupling between classes when building the program.

    By using factory methods to instantiate the sub-controllers within the master-controller, no class in the program (other than this one) will need to have a reference to a sub-controller implementation. This simplifies the program's control scheme and allows for an overall structure with a much looser level of coupling between the controller and the other components.

    When implementing this abstract class, be sure to invoke the appropriate methods explained above in order to maximize functionality.
    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Craig

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected java.util.List<ControllableView> controllableViewList
      A list of all the GUI objects that conform to the ControllableView API, allowing them to be abstractly updated by this controller.
      protected java.util.List<AbstractListSubController<?>> listSubControllerList
      A list of sub-controllers that manage the ListModels for JList GUI objects.
      protected java.util.List<AbstractPropertyModel> propertyModelList
      A list of JavaBean bound property models that this controller is serving as a PropertyChangeListener for.
      protected java.util.List<AbstractPropertySubController> propertySubControllerList
      A list of sub-controllers that manage JavaBean bound properties in models.

      • initLists

        private void initLists()
        Initialize the lists that store the various objects manipulated by this controller.

      • addListSubController

        public void addListSubController(AbstractListSubController<?> listSubController)
        Add a sub-controller that manages the model of a JList to this controller. If list sub-controllers are created through factory methods by an implementation of this class, this method must be invoked by the factory method to save the sub-controller in the list.
        Parameters:
        listSubController - a sub-controller that manages the model of a JList.

      • removeListSubController

        public void removeListSubController(AbstractListSubController<?> listSubController)
        Remove a sub-controller that manages the model of a JList to this controller.
        Parameters:
        listSubController - a sub-controller that manages the model of a JList.

      • addPropertySubController

        public void addPropertySubController(AbstractPropertySubController propertySubController)
        Add a sub-controller that manages a JavaBean bound property model, and adds this controller as a PropertyChangeListener for the sub-controller's model. If property sub-controllers are created through factory methods by an implementation of this class, this method must be invoked by the factory method to save the sub-controller in the list.
        Parameters:
        propertySubController - the controller for a JavaBean bound property model.

      • removePropertySubController

        public void removePropertySubController(AbstractPropertySubController propertySubController)
        Remove a sub-controller that manages a JavaBean bound property model, and removes this controller as a PropertyChangeListener for the sub-controller's model.
        Parameters:
        propertySubController - the controller for a JavaBean bound property model.

      • performViewAction

        public abstract void performViewAction(java.awt.event.ActionEvent event,
                                       java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> propertyValues)
        Perform an action based on user interaction with the view. For implementations of this class, this method should be invoked by any view when an action that will affect the program's state or other major function is called for by the user (ie, through a button click).

        Implementations of this method should pass the parameters to the appropriate handler methods in the sub-classes.
        Parameters:
        event - the event that requires a response.
        propertyValues - data from the view to assist the controller in executing the action.
